dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Agents drive past Abel, who is seated on a park bench overlooking the East River, painting.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (to Driver) Go ahead and park around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE RIVERSIDE
dialogues.text: Abel sets down his palette. Close on his hand, adjusting his easel, then feeling unde the bench. His hand closes on something held by a magnet the bench’s steel frame below the wood seat-slats: it is nickel. Back to Abel sitting. Picks up his palette...

dialogues.speaker: MANHATTAN STREET
dialogues.text: A seedy part of town. Abel walks toward a building, the HOTEL LATHAM.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE ROOM
dialogues.text: As Abel lets himself in. A very modest room. He sets down his portable easel and case. Sets his work-in-progress canvass on a standing easel, drapes his jacket over a cha hangs his hat on the easel. He turns on a table fan. He fishes the nickel from his pocket, retrieves a razor f the bathroom and uses it to carefully to open it. It is hollow. Inside is a piece of paper, folded accordion-style into a small square. Abel unfolds it. Holds it up to a magnifier lamp. Written on the paper, a sequence of numerals.

dialogues.speaker: STREET OUTSIDE HOTEL
dialogues.text: Two government cars skid to a stop and the Agents pour ou

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: The Agents run down the corridor.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 3. ABEL’S ROOM Its door is being busted in. The Agents swarm in. They have guns. They come up short. The small room is empty. The easel with a work in progres upon it stands before the window, which stands open, gent wind playing at the sheers. Outside, a fire escape. The man seems to have left. An Agent inspects a closed door. The bathroom -- Rudolf Abel steps out, in his briefs. Standing in the doorway, cigarette in mouth, we see him as a frail, vulnerable old man. He freezes, not scared, just surprised. He looks at the m They look at him. At last he speaks, with colorless, quasi-British accent.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Visitors. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Would you mind if I fetch my teeth? Two of the agents, Blasco and Gamber, look at each other, confused. Abel gestures back towards the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: BLASCO
dialogues.text: Colonel, would you turn around please. Blasco turns Abel around, checks to make sure he’s not ar

dialogues.speaker: BLASCO, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sit down. On the bed. Blasco and Gamber walk him to the bed. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: (gesturing toward bathroom) The teeth are on the sink... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GAMBER
dialogues.text: Look at me! We are agents from the federal government. Abel scans the Agents who surround him.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look at me! I’m talking to you. We have received information concerning your involvement in espionage. You can either cooperate with us right now or you’ll be under arrest. Do you understand, Colonel? Blasco heads into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Not really. Why do you keep calling me “Colonel”? Blasco returns and with care hands him his teeth. Abel pu them in.

dialogues.speaker: BLASCO
dialogues.text: You need to get dressed.

dialogues.speaker: GAMBER
dialogues.text: We have to search your apartment. Abel points at the art materials on the table.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Would you mind if I cleaned my palette? The paints will get ruined otherwise. Just behind you there. I have a cloth, myself... Abel stands. Blasco hands him his palette.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BLASCO
dialogues.text: (to the other men) Start searching, please.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Would you put this out in the ashtray. On the windowsill there. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: While an Agent does this and the other Agents begin the search, Abel, holding the palette, grabs a small scrap of paper -- the one from the nickel bearing a series of numerals. As the agents explore the room, Abel uses the paper to wi the palette clean.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t want this to get spoiled. The wet paint obliterates the code. As the agents continu to toss the room...

dialogues.speaker: PRE-LAP
dialogues.text: Mellow jazz piano...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two middle-aged men sit in club chairs facing each other. Each holds a tumbler of scotch.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Don't say “my guy.” He’s not “my guy.”

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Yes he’s your guy. Who’re we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: We're talking about a guy who is insured by my client. So don’t make him “my guy.”

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Okay, fine, my point is he -- the guy insured by your client -- he doesn’t deny any of these things happened --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: “These things?”

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Yes. These five things.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Wait. Hold it, hold it, hold it. Not five things, one thing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Clearly, it’s five things.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well -- I’m sorry -- it’s not clear to me. Five things? Explain it to me.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: It’s self-evident.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Okay, then tell me what happened, tell me the story in a way that makes sense. For five things.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Fine. Absolutely. Your guy --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Not my guy. Insured by my client.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: The guy insured by your client -- is driving down State Highway 19 when he loses control of his car, hits my five guys. The five guys who hired me to represent them because you’re not honoring your claim.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: You mean my client is not honoring the claim. The insurance company.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Mr. Donovan: we’re all clear on who’s who here.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Except, my client honors every claim. They do, Mr. Bates, every single legitimate claim. Up to the limit of their liability, which is $100,000 per accident in the case of this man’s policy. And this is one claim, according to your description. “He hit my five guys.” The guy insured by my client had one accident, one one one, losing control of the car and hitting five motorcyclists. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: From their point of view, five things happened.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Look Bob -- may I? Bob? (gestures to self) Jim. If I go bowling and I throw a strike, one thing happened. Ten things didn’t happen.

dialogues.speaker: BATES
dialogues.text: Jim. My clients are not bowling pins. As much your guy might have treated them so --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Lemme finish. If your house is insured to $100,000 and a tornado carries it away, it carried away one house. It didn’t pick up every stick of furniture and destroy it in a separate incident. If that’s what you're saying, well, then there is never any limit to our liability and that is the end of the insurance business. And then, Bob, nobody is safe.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTION
dialogues.text: Donovan steps into a plush office suite. The receptionist works a busy switchboard.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (ON PHONE)
dialogues.text: Watters, Cowan and Donovan, how may I direct your call? Alison, Donovan's secretary, steps over with his mail.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Good morning, Alison.

dialogues.speaker: ALISON
dialogues.text: Morning, Mr. Donovan. I moved your nine a.m. with Prudential, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Why did you do that?

dialogues.speaker: WATTERS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I asked her to -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Donovan turns to find his senior partner, THOMAS WATTERS (70s), watching him closely.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Everything alright, Tom?

dialogues.speaker: WATTERS
dialogues.text: Why don’t you leave your stuff with Alison, c’mon inside. Donovan sets his briefcase, mail and hat down and follows Watters. WATTERS (CONT’D) Something pretty important has come up and there’s someone here to see us. Natalie’1ll get your coffee. (To Watters' secretary Natalie) Nescafé, no cream, two lumps. Right?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: That's right, thanks. He looks concerned. WATTER’S OFFICE Lynn Goodnough (50s), Chairman of the New York Bar, smile Watters and Donovan enter. Goodnough shakes Donovan’s han

dialogues.speaker: GOODNOUGH
dialogues.text: Jim, nice to see you again. How's the family?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Great, good, thanks. How’s Annie? Natalie enters with Donovan’s coffee, sets in on desk.

dialogues.speaker: GOODNOUGH
dialogues.text: Homicidal, we had the in-laws for the holiday. Watters sits on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well, if she acts on it she’1l have good representation. Chuckles. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What’s up? Natalie leaves. All three men take their seats.

dialogues.speaker: GOODNOUGH
dialogues.text: Okay. Here’s the thing. The Soviet spy they caught. We want you to defend him. (pause) Here’s the indictment. Slap! -- he drops a thick document onto the coffee table. Silence. Donovan looks at it but doesn’t reach for it. He is absorbing the news.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well. More silence.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...I’m not sure I should pick that up.

dialogues.speaker: WATTERS
dialogues.text: The accused doesn’t know any lawyers. The Federal Court tossed it into our lap. The Bar Committee took a vote. You were the unanimous choice.

dialogues.speaker: GOODNOUGH
dialogues.text: It was important to us -- it’s important to our country, Jim -- that this man is seen as getting a fair shake. American justice will be on trial.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well, of course, when you put it that way, it’s an honor to be asked. But -- Lynn -- I’m an insurance lawyer, I haven't done criminal work in years.

dialogues.speaker: GOODNOUGH
dialogues.text: Well it’s like riding a bike, isn’t it? You distinguished yourself at Nuremberg. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I was on the prosecution team.

dialogues.speaker: GOODNOUGH
dialogues.text: Not the point: you’re no stranger to criminal law. Jim, look at the situation. The man is publicly reviled.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: And I will be too.

dialogues.speaker: GOODNOUGH
dialogues.text: Yes, in more ignorant quarters. But that’s exactly why this has to be done -- and capably done. It can’t look like our justice system tosses people on the ash heap. Thinking beat.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Suppose I did...what’s the evidence look like?

dialogues.speaker: GOODNOUGH
dialogues.text: Pretty overwhelming.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Great. Great. Everyone will hate me, but at least I’ll lose. (to Watters) What do you think, Tom? The firm’1l suffer, I have work here.

dialogues.speaker: WATTERS
dialogues.text: I think it’s a patriotic duty, this is an important mission. I told Lynn the firm can’t say no, and you'd have a tough time saying no too. I think you have to defend the sonofabitch. DONOVAN’S OFFICE On young attorney Doug Forrester.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: So you're doing it?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Doing what? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Defending Abel, the Soviet spy. Widen to include Donovan, seated at his desk, Forrester standing in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I may be. Hey how do you know? Did they post it on the bulletin board?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I was just talking to Richard --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: If I do this? I’m going to need your help. Doug sits, beams, until -

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can you work tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Well, I have a dinner date, sir... Donovan gives him a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (back-peddling) It’s Tuesday, right? No I can cancel. No problem. As Doug stands and exits, Donovan chuckles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN HOME
dialogues.text: The family is at the dinner table. Mary exits from the kitchen with plates of food.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: ...-But it’s also an honor. And the bar association asked me because they want to demonstrate that even this spy gets a capable advocate. We hear the door opening, off.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well maybe it’s the kind of honor we can do without. People are scared, they’re -- Carol walks in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Hi honey, what are you doing home?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I got stood up.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What? That’s despicable. Who’s this knot head?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’d rather not say.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well sit down, we just started. (to Donovan) ...People are scared, they’re building bomb shelters to protect themselves from people like this man.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Roger. Make another place setting for your sister. Roger does as instructed.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Donovan) I go to the store, people are buying canned foods and potassium tablets. It’s all about this man and what he represents, he’s a threat to all of us, a traitor --

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Who's a traitor?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: The Rosenbergs were traitors --

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Who are they?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: They gave atomic secrets to the Russians. They were Americans, they betrayed their country. But you can’t accuse Abel of being a traitor, he’s not an American. 12. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Listen to yourself. You're defending him already. You're rehearsing it on me. You said you were just thinking about taking it.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well I am just thinking about it -- just very hard. Everyone deserves a defense. Every person matters.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Jim, what do we deserve? You know how people will look at us? The family of a man trying to free a traitor?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: He’s not a traitor, Mary-- The doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Roger get that.

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: Why do I have to do all the work around here? Peggy reaches for a dinner roll.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Wait till we say grace!

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I’m hungry!

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Donovan) He’s about the most unpopular man in the country -- and you're trying to take second place.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yeah, and I’m third.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No, Carol, you just made a date with the wrong guy. (to Mary) Mary, don’t make us disagree if we're not disagreeing, you're against the guy, I’m for him? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Huh-uh. I’m not for the guy, I’m not for Russians spying on us. I’m for his right to have a defense in a court of law. That’s why we call it a court of law... Roger walks back in leading Doug Forrester who is carryin stack of books. Carol stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Hello, sir, sorry -- didn’t mean to interrupt your dinner.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: (still focused on Mary) A court of law and not a...not a... Hey, Doug. And not a kangaroo court.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to Doug) Oh not at all, hello Doug -- Jim was just flailing.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I'm not flailing...go ahead, Doug, you can join us for dinner, we’re having meat loaf tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (ignoring Donovan, eying Doug's books) So you came over to help Jim think about whether he’s taking the case. Doug, deaf to the irony, is innocently enthusiastic:

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Oh, we're taking it! It’s exciting, isn’t it? Mary stares daggers at Donovan. Doug realizes he’s steppe in it. Donovan, abashed, starts saying grace, extends his hand to Mary, who doesn’t hold it so much as slap it...

dialogues.speaker: BROOKLYN COURTHOUSE
dialogues.text: Abel is led by a guard into a detention room where Donova awaits.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 15.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Good morning, sir. My name is Jim Donovan. These are my credentials -- Both men stand looking at each other, Abel still at the threshold. After a beat he moves in further, his gaze holding on Don who glances at papers on table

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m a partner at Watters, Cowan and Donovan. I was admitted to the New York Bar in 1941. As the guard slams the door shut, Abel picks up the paper and inspects them. Donovan watches him, trying to read hi

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «..-You’ve been charged with three counts and nineteen overt acts; conspiracy to transmit United States defense and atomic secrets to the Soviet Union; conspiracy to gather secrets; and failing to register as a foreign agent.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Do many foreign agents register? Only now does Abel look up from the credentials up to Donovan. Donovan takes a moment, not sure if he’s being kidded. He takes a seat at the table.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind my asking, sir, since your arrest: where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: I couldn't say for certain.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: You don’t know. Abel takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: They drove me to an airport, put me on a plane. They took me off the plane. Somewhere hot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: It’s hot here.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Hotter. Very humid. They put me in a room. Abel attends to his runny nose with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Were you beaten?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: No. I was...talked to. Offers were made.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Offers of employment. To work for your government. I was told if I cooperated no further charges would be made against me, and I would be given money.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: And you declined.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: As you see.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well of course, I can’t endorse that. I feel duty bound to urge you to cooperate with the U.S. Government.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Well, I said no. Perhaps you could relay to your friends at the CIA that I meant it.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No no, I don’t work for the agency. I don’t work for the government. I’m here to offer my services as your legal counsel. If you accept them as such, I work for you.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: If I accept you? Are you good at what you do? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Have you represented many accused spies?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No. Not yet. This will be a first for the both of us. Abel chuckles, looks again at Donovan's credentials.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: All right you accept?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Yes, all right.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Good, okay, let’s start here. If you are firm in your resolve not to cooperate with the U.S. government --

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, then do not talk to anyone else about your case. Inside of government or out. Except to me -- to the extent that you trust me. I have a mandate to serve you. Nobody else does. Quite frankly, everybody else has an interest in sending you to the electric chair.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: You don’t seem alarmed. Abel shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Would it help? Abel watches Donovan for another moment. Amused. Pulls ou a pad of paper and starts writing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like materials. To draw with.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: That's not possible.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: A pencil. A piece of paper. And cigarettes. Please. The show of manners surprises Donovan. Abel watches him.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mr. Donovan, you have men like me doing the same for your country. If they were caught, I’m sure you'd wish them to be treated well.

dialogues.speaker: MOTEL
dialogues.text: A cheap room with the curtains drawn. An athletic-looking man in uniform is seated on a chair.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: What’s your name?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Francis Gary Powers. Wider: he is strapped to a lie detector.

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR
dialogues.text: Rank, service.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: First Lieutenant. United States Air Force.

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR
dialogues.text: Do you have any association with the Soviet Union, Lieutenant Powers?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Are you kiddin?

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR
dialogues.text: Just answer the questions, Lieutenant, yes/no or as simply as you can. Do you have any association with the Soviet Union? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Hell no.

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR
dialogues.text: Do you know why you’re here?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Uh-uh.

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR
dialogues.text: Is that a no?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Yes. I mean no. It’s just no. (turning to the interrogator) Yes, I have absolutely no idea why I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATOR
dialogues.text: Eyes front, Lieutenant. Powers turns back.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: EXTERIOR MOTEL
dialogues.text: We are wide looking at the fluorescent-lit arcade of room a motel with a cheap neon sign. Night crickets. The door one room opens and Powers and an escort emerge: Powers is down the row of doors to another, and he is shown in.

dialogues.speaker: NEW ROOM
dialogues.text: Three other pilots are inside, smoking, playing cards, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: How'd ya do in there, Gary?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Pretty good. Think I got my name right.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Probably outscored Shinn, then. Powers sits.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Who's winnin’? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: That would be me.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Deal me in. An officer enters the room and the banter stops. The pilo stand. The officer chuckles and gestures for them to sit. He turns off the flickering TV, takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Okay, drivers, here’s the deal. You have been selected for a mission which you are not to discuss with anyone outside of this room. No one. I don’t care who you trust -- wife, mother, sweetheart, the good lord when you pray at night -- you don’t tell any of ‘em anything of what I’m about to tell you. Each of you drivers has met certain qualifications -- high level security clearance, exceptional pilot ratings, in excess of the required hours flight time ina single seat aircraft. We are engaged in a war. This war does not -- for the moment -- involve men at arms. It involves information. You will be collecting information. You will be gathering intelligence about the enemy -- the intelligence you gather could give us the upper hand in a full thermonuclear exchange with the Soviet Union. Or it could prevent one. For public purposes -- as far as your wife or mother or sweetheart or the good lord above -- your mission does not exist. If it does not exist you do not exist. You cannot be shot down. You cannot be captured. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You work for the CIA now. He smiles, turns, and exits. On the now wary pilots.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 21. BROOKLYN COURTHOUSE -- JUDGE BYERS’ CHAMBERS Judge Byers fixes his tie in a mirror.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE BYERS
dialogues.text: So, Jim, I heard your guy is speaking with a phony accent. Does he keep that up all the time? He turns to Donovan and Assistant Attorney General Willia Tompkins.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Actually I’m pretty sure that’s just the way he talks. He’s got the Russian name but a British passport.

dialogues.speaker: TOMPKINS
dialogues.text: Well I doubt that’s genuine.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE BYERS
dialogues.text: So, Jim, where are we at? I see here you, uh... He is leaning forward, peering through his glasses at a p on his desk. He takes a seat, as do Donovan and Tompkins.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yes, Judge, I -- I just don’t think three weeks is gonna do it here; we've got a massive amount of evidence here --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE BYERS
dialogues.text: You wanna postpone --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Six weeks, I mean there’s just myself and my associate, basically --

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE BYERS
dialogues.text: Jim. Is this serious?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN

dialogues.speaker: PRISON
dialogues.text: Donovan sits at one end of the meeting table. Abel, smoki at the other end. Between them, a radio plays classical music.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: I’ve missed music.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: They checked the radio to make sure there was no transmitter. Abel smiles.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: I’m sure they did. (a beat as he smiles, both men listen, Abel's gaze drifts up) ...Shostakovitch. They listen.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A very great artist, Shostakovitch. Donovan is deep in thought.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I think our strongest grounds for a reversal, are Constitutional. Our best chance is if the Supreme Court agrees to review our case. Abel switches off the radio, removes his glasses.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Jim. You should be careful. Donovan smiles, but uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Careful.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN HOME
dialogues.text: Carol, in curlers, watches TV on the sofa, snacking on pe butter and crackers. Suddenly, the window shatters. Several gun reports, shattering objects. Carol drops the peanut butter jar, crawls under the coffee table. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (screams)

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: A car screeches away.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN HOME
dialogues.text: Mary and Donovan rush to her as she runs to Mary’s arms.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What in God’s name happened? Honey are you all right? Are you hurt?

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Peggy and Roger. Upstairs! Donovan bounds up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN HOME
dialogues.text: Donovan races and squats to put an arm around Peggy to comfort her. Roger is the only one not fearful -- excited, in fact:

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I sat with my back against the wall, Dad! Donovan’s face comes up from where he has been nuzzling Peggy’s head.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: ...What?

dialogues.speaker: ROGER
dialogues.text: I sat with my back against the wall, away from the windows!

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Good...good... good boy. It’s okay. They’re gone. They’re cowards. They’re gone.

dialogues.speaker: DOWNSTAIRS
dialogues.text: Roger inspects the shattered living room window as Donova walks out to the veranda with a plainclothes police lieutenant. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: We'll have detectives canvasing the neighborhood, maybe we'll find a description of the car. I don’t think it’s very - -

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: We're going to need protection.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: I have instructions to leave two cars here, it’ll be pretty obvious this is a secure--

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: For how long? I have to be in Washington later on this week -- A uniformed cop nearby has been listening.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: What’re you doin? What’re you doin to your family?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Pardon me, officer?

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You're still defending this guy. What’re you fighting for him for?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Okay, knock that off, officer --

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Knock off nothing. I was in the third wave at Omaha Beach. Wuddya think about that, buddy?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I did my time in the service --

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: -- fighting these guys? And you’re defending him? What am I not gettin’ here?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Just do your job as an officer of the law! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 56 12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 45.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Okay, I’m sorry (to the cop) Let’s get outside.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No, let's forget about him --

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: What am I not gettin’ here?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT
dialogues.text: Outside, officer. He moves him down the stairs and two other uniformed cops follow them into the street swarming with cop cars, onlookers, reporters. Donovan walks back into the now-quiet living room, where shell-shocked Mary, Carol and Becky lie together on the s Donovan returns to the open front double doors and slams shut.

dialogues.speaker: PESHAWAR USAF BASE
dialogues.text: Williams is briefing the pilots. He stands before a blackboard -- a quick sketch of the U-2 instrument panel.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: Should it become necessary to abandon the aircraft over Soviet territory, then there’s a two and half pound explosive charge contained within the fuselage. He picks up such an explosive from a nearby table and demonstrates.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First, you activate the circuits. But to start the seventy-second timer you need to flip the switch marked destruct. Williams points to a button marked DESTRUCT and he looks meaningfully at the pilots.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is imperative that these flights remain a secret and this equipment does not fall into enemy hands. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: And what about us? Powers is smiling, a half-joke.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAMS
dialogues.text: I don’t know if you're kidding, Lieutenant, I’m not. What you know about the plane is as secret as the plane itself. Silence as this sinks in.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If capture is a foregone conclusion you go down with your plane. If you think you can ditch and get away -- if you’re close enough to a border -- fine, you know the ejection protocol. But if you ditch... He opens a balled fist to show a silver dollar.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: «+-you bring the dollar with you. There’s a pin inside. He withdraws the pin.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAMS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Scratch your skin anywhere. It’s instantaneous. If you think you are about to be captured you use it. Drivers, you understand me? Spend the dollar.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE HANGAR
dialogues.text: A suited-up Powers climbs into a jeep with Murphy and a driver.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: As Donovan walks up the white marble steps.

dialogues.speaker: JEEP
dialogues.text: Pulling up to the U-2 on the airstrip with Powers. The U-2, mechanics finishing their work in service.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 47.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Entering Supreme Court chamber.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Suited up, being fitted with a parachute by Murphy.

dialogues.speaker: SUPREME COURT
dialogues.text: Deafening quiet. Donovan stands at the bench before the justices.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the court. “The Cold War” isn’t just a phrase, Your Honors. It’s not just a figure of speech. Truly a battle is being fought, between two competing views of the world. I contend that Rudolf Ivanovich Abel -- Colonel Abel as he was called even by the men who arrested him -- is our foe in that battle.

dialogues.speaker: AIRSTRIP
dialogues.text: Powers in the cockpit, Murphy going over final checks wit him. Auxiliary power, oxygen supply...

dialogues.speaker: SUPREME COURT
dialogues.text: Donovan continues speaking.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...-He was treated as a combatant in that war until it no longer suited our government to so treat him. Accordingly he was not given the protections we give our own citizens. He was subjected to treatment that, however appropriate to a suspected enemy, was not appropriate to a suspected criminal.

dialogues.speaker: AIRSTRIP
dialogues.text: Powers finalizes his checks. Murphy shakes his hand. The taxis and then soars into the sky, engine roaring.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 48.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I know this man. If the charge is true, he serves a foreign power -- but he serves it faithfully. If he is a soldier in the opposing army -- he is a good soldier. He has not fled the battle to save himself; he has refused to serve his captor, he refused to betray his cause, he has refused to take the coward’s way out. The coward must abandon his dignity before he abandons the field of battle. That, Rudolf Abel will never do. Shouldn’t we, by giving him the full benefit of the rights that define our system of governance, show this man who we are? Who we are: is that not the greatest weapon we have in this Cold War? Will we stand by our cause less resolutely than he stands by his?

dialogues.speaker: STRATOSPHERIC SPACE
dialogues.text: A U-2 banks left into view, its single engine roaring.

dialogues.speaker: U-2 COCKPIT
dialogues.text: Powers moves his hand to the camera trigger, looking into lens. The telephoto lens at the front of the U-2 lets fly, rapi firing as it focuses on the earth below.

dialogues.speaker: U-2 COCKPIT
dialogues.text: Powers is focused on his instruments. A missile trail flashes past to the left: a miss. A violent WHUMP in the cockpit. Powers holds his breath. Powers checks his dials: everything is in one piece. Just then he notices his right wing dipping. He pulls left on stick to level the plane and the plane responds: we seem be getting back to normal. A deafening impact: more violent than the first. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Complete shaking, rocking, diving loss of control. The canopy spiderwebs with cracks. Powers looks down, his legs trapped under his instrument panel. He tries to wriggle free as the U-2 drops at two hundred feet a second. As the plane continues to fall, the earth rushing into vi Powers opens the DESTRUCT button and the canopy shatters, sucking him out of the cockpit. Powers’ faceplate freezes instantly in the sub-zero air. He falls alongside the U-2 it spirals downward and cracks apart, tied to the cockpit his oxygen tube. The plane’s instrument panel begins to freeze over. The DESTRUCT button remains open but unpressed. Power’s oxyge pipe, secured to a tank in the cockpit, begins to rip loo Using the oxygen pipe Powers hauls himself back towards t aircraft. He reaches for the DESTRUCT button but cannot quite reach it. The pipe shears away from its tank and Powers separates f the plane. Man and plane continue to fall alongside one another. The at 15,000 feet, Powers’ parachute automatically opens. A piece of the fuselage barely misses him as he pulls off frozen face plate. He drifts down, the landmass of Russia rising toward him. Powers rips off his faceplate, sucks in air. Far below no the shattered tail of the U-2 shears off. Both wings are torn clean off as the plane hurtles away.

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The President announced that a NASA weather plane disappeared four days ago, north of Turkey...

dialogues.speaker: PRISON RECREATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Abel is working on a painting. The newscast continues, it source the radio that Donovan gave Abel in their last meeting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ANNOUNCER
dialogues.text: .--and the space administration fears that its pilot died in the crash... A brush enters to continue working on the painting. ANNOUNCER (CONT’D) .--Radar showed the plane wandering off course, deep into Soviet territory before contact was lost, complicating any effort to recover it or the remains of the pilot. Now to news out of Washington: in a close vote today the Supreme Court affirmed the conviction of Russian spy, Rudolf Ivanovich Abel, five votes to four. The brush stops momentarily. Wider on Abel, paused at his work. ANNOUNCER (CONT’D) .-.-The case presented civil liberties issues according to the Russian's lawyer, James B. Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN HOME
dialogues.text: Mary stands at the open refrigerator, holding grocery ite listening attentively to the same broadcast. ANNOUNCER (CONT’D) When asked how he felt about today’s loss, Mr. Donovan simply said, “Tired.” I'll have more news for you after this message. Mary breathes a sigh of relief.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to herself) It’s over...

dialogues.speaker: WATTERS, COWAN
dialogues.text: Donovan walks through the busy office to a desk.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Marty, I'll be danmed if I can find the file on that Prudential case. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The young men stands.

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: I, uh...Mr. Watters asked me to move it over to Jack Elwe’s office. Along with the first draft of the appeal.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: He did?

dialogues.speaker: MARTY
dialogues.text: He redrafted and filed it last week. While you were in Washington.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: Donovan approaches Watters’ office, where Tom Watters is meeting with what appears to be the principal partners in firm.

dialogues.speaker: WATTERS
dialogues.text: How long have we been together now, and you act as if I’ve never closed a deal? Set up a meeting, someplace fancy. The door stands ajar. Watters looks up and sees Donovan, waves. He meets Donovan’s look, without warmth, and pointedly turns back to the table to continue. WATTERS (CONT’D) I’m betting Mr. Young would like some of the finer things New York has to offer. Donovan listening -- no invitation to join. Natalie exits with a tea pot and the door closes in his face. Allison is sorting mail. As Donovan walks away she approaches him with a letter in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: ALISONL
dialogues.text: Do you know anyone from Leipzig?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: More hate mail? From Germany now?

dialogues.speaker: ALLISON
dialogues.text: From East Germany. She hands it to him.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 52.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON
dialogues.text: Abel is reading the letter. He still has the sniffles. Donovan stands next to him, waiting for him to finish reading.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Is it your wife?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: No, no, no, no. She pretends to be, but it’s not even good pretense. He looks back down at the letter, reads:

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .-."I am taking this liberty to write to you after having learned from the newspapers about your most humane attitude towards my beloved husband, Rudolf Abel.” He looks up, chuckling.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: And do I write back? Abel shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Ya, ya, ya -- what’s the next move when you don’t know what the game is? He hands the letter back to Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: HALL OF TRADE UNIONS
dialogues.text: A man standing beside Powers, translating the Russian jud voice that is being amplified by loudspeakers:

dialogues.speaker: TRANSLATOR
dialogues.text: -.. U.S.S.R. laws on criminal responsibilty for state crimes, to ten years of confinement, with the first three years to spent in prison. The term of the confinement... He drones on as a stricken Powers absorbs the translation Widen to show the thousands gathered in the majestic hall now standing and cheering the sentence.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 53.

dialogues.speaker: CIA HEADQUARTERS
dialogues.text: Donovan sits, waiting, and staring at the CIA seal on the wall. CIA HEADQUARTERS -- DULLES’ OFFICE As Donovan enters.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Donovan, thank you so much for coming.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: It’s a pleasure to meet you, Mr. Dulles. It’s an honor, sir. Allen Dulles (70's) hands Donovan a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Nescafe, cream, two lumps.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. Dulles lifts the letter from a sideboard.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Okay. This letter you received. It seems pretty clear that the Soviets are making an overture here. They're doing it through East Germany because they still don’t want to acknowledge Abel is a Soviet citizen much less a Soviet spy. So, a lot of fiction going on.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yes sir. But -- to what end?

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: They've got our guy, our spy pilot, we've got their guy. He hands the letter to agent Hoffman.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A prisoner exchange. I think that’s what they’re after. Which could hardly be a surprise to you, counselor: it’s an eventuality that I think you foresaw. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I sure did. And I’m so rarely right. Dulles chuckles. The three men cross the large office to Dulles’ desk, where he takes a seat and Donovan and Hoffm do the same.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Well congratulations. Red-letter day. Now, we have our man over there, Powers -- a good man -- but with a...with a head full of classified information. Abel has a head full of classified information, too, but he hasn’t given us a lick.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: And, sir, take it from me -- he won't.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Yes, we know that but the Russians don't. They want their man back before he cracks and we want Powers back for the same reasons.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I think you’re saying, sir, there might be a happy ending for everybody --

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Yes, if we, um, indulge their fiction. He lights a pipe, studies Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We want you to negotiate the swap because you’re a private citizen, so it’s not governments talking. They don't acknowledge Abel as a Soviet citizen and we don’t acknowledge East Germany as a sovereign country. We haven't recognized East Berlin since it was annexed by the Soviets in ‘45.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: So I act as negotiator, representing (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: You're not representing anybody. You're not a government official, you have no official standing.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: So...some fiction on our side as well.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Correct. Which means of course you can’t rely on any acknowledgment or help if things go south. The CIA can’t be responsible, we can’t be embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: And where do they want this negotiation to take place?

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: ...There?

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: East Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: But isn’t East Berlin getting rather...

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Well, yes, the place is getting...complicated.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, complicated. The Soviet side has been setting up checkpoints for the past few months to try to stop people hemorrhaging to the Western sectors. It hasn’t worked. We have intelligence to suggest that they May go one step further and wall off the entire Eastern sector. Donovan is concerned, thinking...

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Okay -- that’s it in a nutshell. The decision is entirely yours. If you need time to kick it around... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: After a pensive beat --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No. No, I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Well fine! Fine! He rises to shake Donovan’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of course it’s be best if this all remains confidential. Let’s not discuss any of this with, uh...(a discreet look to an open file on the table) Mary, or with anyone else. Share the correspondence only with us. It’ll let us know what they want to do, and when. All three men walk toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I have no client, no wife, no government. Don’t quite know what I’m doing, or when, or who for.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: You're doing it for your country. But your country doesn’t know that yet.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What about my client, the other person in this equation -- my guy.

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: “Your guy”? You mean the Russian? He’s not your guy any more, counselor, your guy is Francis Gary Powers now.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: And what do I tell Rudolf Abel?

dialogues.speaker: DULLES
dialogues.text: Tell him not to drop dead.

dialogues.speaker: SUPER
dialogues.text: A tank and a fleet of army trucks with Soviet markings in streets of Berlin. Easst German soldiers work with pick-a and shovels. Soldiers break up the concrete ground. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hundreds of East German digging a foundation through the heart of the city. Two parents rush by, carrying their child, trying to cros Pryor, a young American student walking his bike, watches He mounts his bike and rides along the wall, a camera aro his neck and a satchel slung over his shoulder. Eastern Berliners trying to cross are dragged back by soldiers. One mother with her children shouts across to her husband stranded on the Eastern side. As the wall reaches further upward, more and more people arrive on both sides. Some climb down from apartment windows, dangling, while others below try to catch them.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STREET
dialogues.text: Pryor, now walking his bicycle, arrives at a gap in the construction. Supplies here are piled up but no workers h yet been dispatched to this section. A brief look back and forth, and then Pryor pushes his bi into the Eastern sector.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: Pryor pulls up outside an austere-looking apartment block He leans his bike against the wall, enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT INTERIOR
dialogues.text: The door is ajar, German radio coming from inside. Pryor enters. The apartment is the book-crowded domain of an academic. Pryor projects over the sound of the radio.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR
dialogues.text: Professor? A young woman -- Katje -- emerges from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: KATJE
dialogues.text: Papa went to the University. You shouldn’t be here, Frederic.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR
dialogues.text: They're having classes today? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: KATJE
dialogues.text: He went to see. It’s where he goes. What’re you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR
dialogues.text: I came to get you and your father. You have to come with me. You might not get out tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: KATJE
dialogues.text: Just -- leave?

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, yes, leave. Right now.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: The young man and young woman push their bikes quickly, a tanks and soldiers. Up ahead is the street where he crossed through, into the East. Soldiers are now at work there.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR
dialogues.text: Go back. Go back. A few armed soldiers notices the couple. They start towar them.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll be okay, I’m American. Go back to your father’s, we’ll find another way, just go. She eases off, starts to walk away. The soldier calls to her in German. She turns, walking backwards, shrugs, answers in German, still retreating. The soldiers are upon Pryor. Pryor holds his palms up in apology.

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Papers. Please.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR
dialogues.text: Ich bin Student. Frederic Pryor, I - (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The soldier yells at him as he reaches forward, grabs the camera round his neck and yanks it, snapping the strap. H shakes the camera in Pryor’s face, yelling. A second soldier grabs his bike and tosses it aside.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My name is Frederic Pryor. I’m an economics student. Student. He withdraws a binder from his satchel.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s my dissertation, my thesis. The Foreign Trade System of the European Communist Nations. The soldier takes it from him.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There’s a lot of work... The soldier hands it off to another soldier.

dialogues.speaker: PRYOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (as he reaches for it) And that’s my only copy -- The reach was a mistake: as the second soldier knocks him down. Katje, watching from a distance, is terrified for h

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN HOME
dialogues.text: A rushed DONOVAN is tossing dress shirts into an open suitcase on the bed. MARY watches tersely.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Came up at the last minute. They have offices in London. These clients, not my idea, Scotland, a fishing expedition. It’s obvious to Donovan that she doesn’t believe a word. Mary’s too smart for this, and of late, their life has be far too strange.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (pointedly) What kind of fishing, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Salmon fishing... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Just tell me that you’re not going to be in any danger. That it’s a routine business trip, and I won't worry. Donovan keeps moving; he doesn’t have time to pause.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I need my passport. She opens the dresser drawer so he can retrieve it.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Just give me something to hold onto. I don’t even care if it’s the truth. Donovan reaches for her, gently holds her waist.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: (the truth) I am doing this for us.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE CARD
dialogues.text: A black sedan drives through the snow, away from the cent airport. Donovan is in the back seat middle, Hoffman and Agent Pin on either side.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Michener here is your Berlin escort. He’s an attaché with the US Embassy. He refers to the State Department man in the front passen seat. The driver is someone with an extremely thick neck fleshy ears. Michener has his arm hooked around the seat to talk back.

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER
dialogues.text: So...it’s gotten goddamn complicated.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER
dialogues.text: As you know, the last letter from “Mrs. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Abel,” whoever she is, talks about her lawyer in East Berlin, Mr. Vogel, whoever he is. “Representing her interests,” she says.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Vogel says he’s gone to the Russian embassy in East Berlin, and they may be ready to trade Abel for Powers. We don’t know who’s who, but they’re all basically the Russian, right?

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER
dialogues.text: Well, Soviet -- we think so.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Wuddya mean? Can we turn up the heat in here? Michener talks to the driver in German. The man shrugs, tweaks a knob on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER
dialogues.text: There’s a wrinkle -- uh -- uh -- they might try to throw you a curve ball, try and get you to accept another prisoner other than Powers.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Another American?

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER
dialogues.text: The East German Stasi picked up an American student -- Frederic Pryor -- a kid they found on the wrong side of the wall. He’s a grad student out of Yale, came over here to study economics. So, they’re making noises about trying this kid for espionage, grave offense, capital crime. Well: Vogel got in touch with us, said he represents Pryor.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Vogel represents “Mrs. Abel,” and this kid?

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER
dialogues.text: Yeah, he’s -- busy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: So -- what is he? He really is East German? Or Russian?

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER
dialogues.text: Well -- try to figure it out when you meet him. Russian Embassy, East Berlin, noon tomorrow. Hoffman will show you how to get there.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Show me how to get there? But I’m going to have an escort. Uncomfortable silence; Donovan notes it.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Right? Michener is uncomfortable:

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER
dialogues.text: Well, that was the plan, but -- like I said, there’s a wrinkle. I won’t be taking you. The decision has been made, no U.S. government personnel are to cross the border until further notice.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: MICHENER
dialogues.text: Too dangerous. The East Germans grabbed this kid. There’s a degree of impunity, uh, that we had not anticipated. The point is that the East German agenda, and the Russian agenda, may not be the same thing. You try to figure it out. And act accordingly: try to make a deal -- Powers for Abel.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well what about this college kid, Pryor?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t fall for that. We can get him out another time. Powers is the whole ballgame. The sedan pulls up to a remote looking house - a safe hou  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 63.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: A bedroom with an disheveled unmade bed. The living room piled with old newspapers. Donovan turns to Hoffman. It’s so cold in here you can see the men’s breath.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Where’s your room?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I‘ll be staying at the Hilton. It’s not far. He hands Donovan a slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a number here in West Berlin. Memorize it, and give it back to me. Donovan puts it in his shirt pocket.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No. I mean now. Donovan sighs, looks at the paper.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Soviets keep cutting international lines, but local calls are okay. Someone will pick up day and night. Donovan hands the piece of paper back. Hoffman takes out lighter, burns the paper and drops it into an ashtray.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (holding up Donovan's passport) Now this docket, attached to your passport, will serve as your ticket into and out of the Eastern Soviet sector. The meeting with Vogel is set for noon tomorrow. He unfolds a map on the table.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are only a few routes left to the East. You take the S-Bahn, the station we showed you on the way in. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to get off at the Friedrichstrasse Station, here, and walk to the Soviet Embassy on Unter den Linden, here. Look at the map now -- you shouldn’t take it with you. You're looking at a map, you're an American, you’re a spy, you could well be detained. Just avoid interaction with people, generally -- you don’t belong, so don’t stick out. Food is scarce over there and things have started to fall apart. There are gangs; rule of law is less...firmly established over there. And definitely stay away from the Wall. On their side, there’s a line cleared of buildings, along the Wall, they call it the Death Line. Cross it and you'll be shot.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Is there any outcome here where I’m not either detained, or shot?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry too much about what Michener said.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No, now I’m worried about what you're saying. This kid Pryor, that the East German’s have. How old is he?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Twenty-five, why?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: That’s the same age as Dougie.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: An associate of mine...

dialogues.speaker: EAST GERMAN POLICE/PRISON FACILITY
dialogues.text: Katje is sitting at a table in a bare room. Very still.

dialogues.speaker: KATJE
dialogues.text: Frederic Pryor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Katje is holding a picture of Frederic Pryor. The officia doesn’t even look at it, continues reading his newspaper. The following exchange is in German, subtitled.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, there is nothing I can tell you. After a deflated beat, a plea:

dialogues.speaker: KATJE
dialogues.text: He’s not here, or you can’t tell me he’s here? Where is he? The man shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICIAL
dialogues.text: I can’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON CELL
dialogues.text: Pryor sits at a small table in his cell, eating.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE A TRAIN
dialogues.text: It is a gray day. Donovan sits looking out. His point-of- view: approaching the Wall. It comes at us, foreshortenin and then sweeps by: a ragged line stretching into the background, punctuated by guard towers. On its far side i swath of cleared land. Even beyond this Death Line many of the buildings of the are bombed out, the war damage still largely unrepaired. There is not much life in the streets.

dialogues.speaker: FRIEDRICHSTRASSE STATION
dialogues.text: Passengers disembarking, Donovan among the last. A long line stretching up to a checkpoint. Only one soldi checks papers, though many soldiers stand about. Donovan looks at his watch. Tense. He thinks, decides. He steps out of the line and marches to the front, drawin looks. Approaching the checkpoint: the soldier checking papers l up at him, surprised. This doesn’t happen. A couple soldiers tighten grips on their guns. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Donovan holds out his passport and summons a degree of sternness as, in broken German, he tries to explain his plight. The soldiers search his passport and wallet as he points at his watch urgently. The soldiers search his documents and slowly all of them begin to relax when they see he’s American. They let him pass.

dialogues.speaker: STREET
dialogues.text: Donovan walking. It is snowing heavily. He reaches an intersection. Several youths are gathered there -- mangy strays. They eye Donovan as they approach, slowing. He eyes them, not slowing. They pass, but several paces on Donovan senses something wrong. He turns. One of them, the biggest of the group, speaks to him in German. Clearly it is a question. They all look at him, awaiting answer. Donovan stares, uncomprehending. The big guy repeats the question. This time impatiently. He grabs Donovan’s coat by a lapel. Examines the material

dialogues.speaker: HEAD YOUTH
dialogues.text: So.... We apologize. If this offends? Donovan realizes they are demanding his coat. He asks for directions to Unter den Linden. The Head Youth points out the directions. Donovan shrugs out of the coat, ceding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking towards the street: Donovan is a small figure. He wears only his suit. He’s freezing. He runs. New angle: he stands before an imposing building, in good repair: the embassy. He heads for its door.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 67.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE
dialogues.text: Donovan comes to a reception desk.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Do you understand English?

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I’m James Donovan. I’m here to meet a Mr. Vogel.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: Mr. Vogel?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: He doesn’t work here. I’m just supposed to meet him. That’s all I know.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICE
dialogues.text: Some minutes later. The receptionist is showing Donovan i though a series of magnificent rooms to a parlor of sorts There are three people in the room: a woman in her fiftie much younger woman, and an older man in a three-piece sui The older woman is effusively emotional and charges Donov weepily:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Donovan! So we finally meet you! She hugs him, Donovan stiffly unresponsive.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -..I am Helen Abel! How is our husband? How is Rudolf?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: He’s... good as can be expected --

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: And we will get him back, yes? This is our daughter, Lydia...

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: How do you do? (to the older man) And you’re Mr. Vogel? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The man is momentarily thrown. He recovers, laughing:

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: No no no no. Not Vogel, no. I am cousin Drews. He vigorously shakes Donovan’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: This is Rudolf’s beloved cousin Drews.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Cousin Drews.

dialogues.speaker: DREWS
dialogues.text: I am Cousin Drews.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Cousin Drews, yes.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I’m Helen Abel! An awkward pause...

dialogues.speaker: HELEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When will you see him? She pulls him down to a small sofa.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When will your government release him?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I’m a little...lost here. I’m supposed to meet a Mr. Vogel.

dialogues.speaker: LYDIA AND DREWS
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Vogel is our lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yes, and I thought we were supposed to negotiate the exchange.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: To bring Rudolf here.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well yes...yes, to bring him here, but it doesn’t happen unilaterally. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you understand? It has to be an exchange... Helen bursts into tears. 69. Lydia puts an arm around her to comfort her. Cousin Drews kneels in front of the sobbing woman, comforting her as w Donovan dubiously watches this show. A door clicks open -- not the one Donovan entered by but set into a panel of the wall near the mirror behind the d A man enters.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Donovan. Donovan rises, extending a hand.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Vogel? Shaking hands, his manner dry, urbane:

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: No no, no. My name is Schischkin, Ivan Schischkin. I am second secretary of the Soviet Embassy. It would not be appropriate for Mr. Vogel to join us; he is a German national.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: So you are...here to...

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: To facilitate this meeting. (to the group on the couch) Perhaps Mrs. Abel would like to compose herself privately? And let Mr. Donovan and myself to talk? The group takes the cue and leaves by the main door, face suddenly stern. Now the room is quiet. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: So, I’m confused...

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Yes. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I don’t care who I talk to if it’s about an exchange of...personnel. Are you the person to talk to?

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Yes yes -- of course we should talk. Please, have a seat. Sit down. They sit opposite one another at a small table. SCHISCHKIN (CONT’D) So, how did you arrive in the Eastern sector?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: The train. The S-Bahn.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: You were alone?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: And you are credentialed --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: You must know about me, sir. I'ma private citizen, a lawyer in Brooklyn -- in the United States -- and I’ve taken some time out of a busy schedule to help my client, Rudolf Abel. I’m authorized to arrange an exchange of Abel for Francis Gary Powers -- this is a full pardon of Abel (handing a paper across) that will be signed when the exchange actually takes place. That’s the only reason I’m here. I hope and expect to make this arrangement quickly -- Abel for Francis Gary Powers (a measured beat) and -- Frederic Pryor.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: We don’t have Pryor.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No? You don’t? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: I've heard of Pryor. But he is held by German Democratic Republic, not by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Schischkin hands him back the pardon.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well, I’11 tell you the first problem, the names of your countries are too long. Schischkin smiles. Donovan's

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: If we release Powers it is only to promote good will between our countries. So it cannot be an exchange. Perhaps you could release Abel as a token of good will to our friends in Germany, and then some months later we would release Powers, there’s an idea.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No, that won’t work for us at all, you see we need this to be an exchange. You can call it what you want, but an exchange it must be. We can have Abel within forty-eight hours. We need Powers at the same time we give you Abel.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Well this is -- can we call this “The Impatient Plan”?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Call it whatever you want. cold’s getting worse. He blows his nose.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: I can relay your Impatient Plan to Moscow, see what they say. But they will wonder, why so Impatient?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Because I have a cold, I don’t live in Berlin, and I want to get home. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: They will think, well, the Americans must have gotten all the information that Abel had to give. And now they are now impatient to trade him, hoping to get in return this man Powers who perhaps has not yet given up the information that he has to give. This is not an equitable trade, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: But you’re saying, if Powers has given up everything he knows, then Moscow would trade? Why wouldn’t they? As for Abel, if he dies in an American prison, the next Russian operative who gets caught might think twice about keeping his mouth shut...(and now he tries something new) and, you never know, Abel might want to see the sky again and start to trade Russian secrets for very small American favors.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: How can we know this. We little men, we just do our jobs.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Like Lt. Powers. He’s just a pilot.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: He was making photographs from seventy thousand feet when he was shot from the sky. People in my country consider this an act of war.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: We have to get off this merry go round, sir. The next mistake our countries make could be the last one. We need to have the conversation our governments can’t. Schischkin takes a moment to think. Donovan watches him a waits.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: I will ask Moscow. Who knows what they will say? A lot of people, Mr. Donovan, don’t want this exchange to ever take place. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rises. 12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 73. (6)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As does Donovan. SCHISCHKIN (CONT’D) Can you come back tomorrow and discuss their answer? Powers for Abel.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: And Frederic Pryor.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: (patient) As I said, Pryor is in the hands of the organs of state security of the German Democratic Republic.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I’m confident you can make arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: I am merely a secretary in the embassy of a foreign power.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: You’1ll have to see Mr. Vogel. I/’11 give you his address. Donovan looks at him for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: ...-There actually is a Mr. Vogel?

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Why would you imagine otherwise? It’s a short cab ride. (writing) And please, Mr. Donovan, wear an overcoat in this weather.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I had mine stolen from me.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: What did you expect? (handing him the address) It was from Saks Fifth Avenue. Wasn’t it? On Donovan, as this sinks in.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 74.

dialogues.speaker: BUILDING
dialogues.text: A secretary shows Donovan in. A man better-dressed than h office would lead you to expect, is pouring two scotches: Wolfgang Vogel.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Mr. Donovan!

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Vogel.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Please come in!

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry about the embassy, the Soviets decided not to host us, very irritating.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I am still trying to grasp each party’s...

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Status?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yes. And interest, in the proceedings.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Yes, a new world, all very disorienting isn’t it. He hands Donovan one of the tumblers, and they both drink

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let me tell you what I have to offer. I ama good friend -- friend, no, he is older -- protégé -- of the Attorney General of the German Democratic Republic. Sit down please. They sit across from each other at Vogel's desk.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This unfortunate Frederic Pryor, well, he was in the wrong place at the wrong time. But every accident, properly viewed, is an opportunity, isn’t it Mr. Donovan? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well --

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Your country refuses to recognize the German Democratic Republic. They prefer to make up stories -- that the GDR doesn’t exist, for instance. Donovan signals that his glass is empty.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sorry. He rises to refill it.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As a means of forcing your government’s recognition of this real place, sir, in which you find yourself -- the GDR. The Attorney General is happy to negotiate with you, aS a representative of your government, for Mr. Pryor’s return.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Vogel, I’m not here as a representative of my government. Silent beat.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: (sadly) All right. I think that’s childish, Mr. Donovan. Donovan shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well, I have no official status.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: ...Fine, you do not represent the USA, I do not represent the GDR. My client is Lydia Abel, Rudolf’s wife, and I have also --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Lydia is the daughter. Helen is the wife. A beat, Vogel resentful at having his thought derailed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Well. I -- am prepared to offer Frederic Pryor’s exchange, for Rudolph Abel’s. Donovan stands, faces off with him.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well let’s be clear. We will produce Rudolf Abel. At the same time, you will produce, the student Pryor. At the same time.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Absolutely. Vogel takes a photograph from a file on his desk top. The photo is of an incarcerated Pryor, looking very young and very scared. He hands it to Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The exchange on offer is a Russian at the end of his life, for an American student at the start of his. Donovan stares at the photo of the innocent young man.

dialogues.speaker: SAFE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Hoffman strides toward Donovan, who is wrapped in a blank for warmth, and sets down a cup of tea for him and a bott of wine. Michener and Pinker read newspapers in the background.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: “Schischkin”? He’s not an embassy secretary. Ivan Schischkin is the KGB’s chief in Western Europe.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well -- okay. Whatever he is. He’s relaying the proposal to Moscow and they’1l decide -- could I borrow your coat? I lost mine. Hoffman stares at him, thrown by the veer off-course.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: How did you lose your coat?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: You know. Spy stuff. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Hoffman gazes at him, deadpan. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I’1ll get you another coat.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Good. Good. So -- who is this Vogel?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Him we don’t know. He might be what you said he is, friend of the Attorney General. Just some guy the GDR tapped to handle this. Sounds like the East Germans are fighting for a place at our table. The GDR gets Abel back for the Russians, winning their respect, and captures the headlines for their cause. Which of course puts East Germany on the map. But we don’t care about their map. Stick with the Russians. Stick with the Russians. It’s Powers for Abel.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: So, does all this mean it might actually -- happen?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: That's what you seem to be telling me. We’ll put Abel on a plane, he’ll be here Friday. So if Schischkin gets the okay, all that’s left is the mechanics of the trade, how we swap our guy for their guy.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Our guys. Two guys. Powers and Pryor.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: No! Don’t go bleeding heart on me! Powers is the whole ballgame. Forget this Ivy League boy, who obviously thought it was a good idea to study Soviet economics in Berlin in the middle of the Cold War. Powers is who we need.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: You don’t even like Powers. Everybody hates Powers. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He didn’t kill himself, he let the commies parade him on television, he’s the most hated man in America. After Rudolf Abel, maybe. And me.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON CELL
dialogues.text: Gary Powers, fitfully sleeping. Two guards reach in to haul him up.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: No, no...

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gary Powers being marched down a hall.

dialogues.speaker: GARY POWERS
dialogues.text: Being pushed down onto a seat in a dark interrogation roo He blinks blearily as a bright overhead light ignites.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: I need to sleep. I need to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I told you: you can sleep once we talk. But we need to talk. You must focus on me. Your government does not care about you. You know that. Any of you. You know that twelve U-2 pilots incurred brain damage. They are vegetables. Because of altitude, insufficient oxygen. But they keep you flying, Gary. You and your friends. They gave you this, didn’t they? (holding out the silver dollar) A scratcher, yes, potassium cyanide? (pops open the coin) Does that look like they care about you?

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Gary Powers being marched back to his cell.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 79. GARY POWERS’ CELL Gary Powers is escorted to his bed, where he flops down, instantly closing his eyes. The overhead light goes out. The cell door slams closed. A time jump... Now the overhead light glares on. Gary Powers’ door is fl open. Two men pull him to his feet and drag the still sleeping Powers out into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Powers marched down the long hall.

dialogues.speaker: INTERROGATION ROOM
dialogues.text: Powers in the chair. His eyes fluttering between wake and sleep. A bucket of cold water poured over his head. Four interrogate him.

dialogues.speaker: MAN 1
dialogues.text: What is the construction of the destructor unit? By what means is this unit operated?

dialogues.speaker: MAN 2
dialogues.text: With what explosives is the unit charged? And what destruction is it capable of?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: I don’t know. The pilots were never shown any of the equipment.

dialogues.speaker: MAN 3
dialogues.text: How wide-far can the radar map an area during an overflight?

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: I don’t know! I don’t know!

dialogues.speaker: MAN 1
dialogues.text: Were you making the overflight on April 9th, over the industrial area and the bomber base.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: I was not. This was my first overflight. (CONTINUED)
