dialogues.speaker: MAN 4
dialogues.text: I need to know about engine out-to- glide ratio-- how the plane get so high. We know it reaches altitude of 70,000 feet. Gary, we know this. I need to know where the planes have flown. Where they have flown, Gary. And we must have this talk now. Now. And then, you can sleep a little.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Powers locked back into his cell.

dialogues.speaker: PRISON CELL
dialogues.text: Abel sleeping. A hand enters to shake him awake.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Sir... Abel stirs, looks up. A civilian, not a guard, stands over him. This is Avalon. Two other civilians linger at the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Sir, could you come with me please? We need to move, could you come with me? Abel groggily sits up, swings his legs out.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: ..-What time is it?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: It’s late. But we need to talk, and then get on a plane.

dialogues.speaker: EMBASSY MEETING ROOM
dialogues.text: Donovan sits before Schischkin.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: So, I have received a favorable decision from Moscow on your proposal that we help our friends in the German Democratic Republic, by exchanging Mr. Powers for Mr. Abel. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: That’s swell!

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: May I suggest the Glienicke Bridge as a place for the swap.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Why not Checkpoint Charlie?

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Well, we are not looking for publicity! Glienicke Bridge is very quiet. Especially early morning.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Glienicke Bridge, I‘1l run that by our side. We can have Abel here on Friday, so -- Saturday morning?

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Always impatient, yes?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’ve gotta get back home and get into bed. So, Saturday morning?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: All right. We’re done here. This is a number (writing)...in case anything should come up...Someone will answer, at any hour.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: (taking the paper) All right. I don’t expect to use it. Shall we toast the arrangement?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Why not. Schischkin heads for a sideboard, holds up a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Armenian brandy. Good bracer for your cold. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Thank you. Would you mind -- it’s not part of our business but I’d like to ask a couple of questions? You do not have to answer.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: I shall answer what I know. Schischkin returns with the drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I like this guy. Your guy. What happens to your guy...when he gets home?

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Well. We have to make a determination whether our guy is now...your guy.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: As I said to you before, he’s acted very honorably. He’s still your guy, believe me.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Of course: you would say this if it were true, and if it were not true.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I guess it has come down to that... Forgive me for pushing, but...is he in any danger? If the determination is made...

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Well, goodness. As things are now, everyone is in danger. Cheers. He raises his glass. Donovan toasts him in Russian. The toast is interrupted by a knock. A secretary puts his head in.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: A message for Mister Donovan... VOGEL’S OFFICE The familiar squalid counterpoint to Schischkin’s Louis X swank. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dapper Vogel in a new change, as incongruously fine in th office as was his last one. But his manner is different, at all the happy fixer of yesterday. His tone is cold as Donovan, dabbing at his nose, is shown in.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: There will be no exchange on Glienicke Bridge. Vogel rises and reaches for some files he puts into his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: There will be no exchange. Not for Frederic Pryor.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Vogel. I thought yesterday -- we agreed --

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: We agreed on an exchange: Abel for Pryor. Now I learn you are a rug merchant selling the same rug to two customers. Abel for Pryor, you sell to us. Abel for Powers, you sell to the Soviets. Vogel's secretary helps him on with his overcoat and scar

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: .-.I’m not sure I understand the problem. If the arrangement satisfies two parties, or three, or four, what difference --

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: The arrangement does not satisfy this party. He exits into the corridor and Donovan follows.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Now Mr. Vogel, please --

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Obviously you do not know who you are dealing with. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here is the interest of the German Democratic Republic: to deal with, and to be seen to be dealing with, another sovereign power, the United States. An equal power. Instead you treat us as stooges for the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Can we just call them “the Russians” -- it’ll save time.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: I have an appointment sir. I think it is you who are wasting time. He heads down the stairs; Donovan follows.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Tell me if I’m describing this wrong. You have a kid, a university student, somebody you know is not a spy, and no threat to you. In exchange for this person, worthless to you, you play an equal part in an exchange with two other powers, the Americans and the Russians.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: The two men emerge from the building.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: It’s one transaction, between us and the two of you. We’re not trying to do two different things here. It’s one thing. One one one. And it’s hard for me to see how the Republic of East German Democrats is being slighted.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: You arranged with the Soviets without consulting me. Is this a negotiation -- or a conspiracy?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: For it to be a conspiracy, there would have to be some harm to you, sir. There’s just benefits here. We have agreeing interests -- 84. Vogel is climbing into a fancy sports car parked at the c (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: No. You decide they agree.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Where’s is your appointment, sir?

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: In the West.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Good. Donovan opens the passenger door and climbs inside.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Look around you. 85. The car is racing through a desolate cityscape. Donovan d look around; takes it in.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How does the Eastern sector compare to the West? (no answer) Our Russian friends have decided that we should not rebuild our capital city. We live in this ruin. Made by our Russian friends. Go ahead, make your deal with these Russians, but we won't be part of it.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: There is no deal without Pryor. We’re not leaving him here. The car rounds a corner at speed.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Is that your position, or your government's?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I'm here. I’m talking to you.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: But you’re not a representative of the government. You don’t know who you are. Neither do we. You should be careful. This is not Brooklyn, Mr. Donovan. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The speedometer, the needle at 120kph

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Sir: you must know that in the respect that matters, I represent my government. You know who I am.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Do I?

dialogues.speaker: INTO TOP GEAR, GUTTING THE ENGINE AS IT SPEEDS ALONG. A
dialogues.text: SIREN. VOGEL’S GAZE SWITCHES TO THE REAR VIEW MIRROR. HE SMILES.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. Donovan looks behind. A police detail comes up on their tail. Vogel downshifts, lifting his foot off the gas. Vogel pulls over. Donovan is suddenly nervous as they ski to a stop. The police sedan pulls up behind them.

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you have the proper papers? Oh, no of course you don’t. It doesn’t matter. An expensive American lawyer like you can talk your way out of anything. Can’t you. Vogel gets out of the car. He speaks to the cops in Germa Nods toward Donovan, saying he’s an American. The cops tr Vogel deferentially -- but not Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
dialogues.text: (sharpy, in German, to Donovan as he opens the passenger door.) You, get out now. Donovan climbs out of the car, hands over his passport.

dialogues.speaker: POLICE OFFICER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in German) Passport. Donovan hesitates, he looks at Vogel. The checkpoint guard checks Donovan’s passport, shouts something in German to another guard, and then to Donovan English. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Go with him.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Passport. Problem.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What? What’s wrong with it? What problem? The other guard has stepped in, hand on his gun.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: Go with him. As Vogel is led away:

dialogues.speaker: VOGEL
dialogues.text: And remember. We control the fate of Frederic Pryor.

dialogues.speaker: CELL
dialogues.text: Pryor is awake. Pacing. His light is off as he can see an armed guard positioned on the grate above. Pryor is utter terrified.

dialogues.speaker: CELL
dialogues.text: Powers, eyes open, alone in his cell and staring at the p and pencils on the table in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: CARGO PLANE INTERIOR
dialogues.text: Avalon leads Abel to a seat. Abel is holding a cardboard tube.

dialogues.speaker: HOLDING ROOM
dialogues.text: A holding room door is opened. Donovan rises from the uncomfortable bench he’s been on.

dialogues.speaker: S-BAHN
dialogues.text: Donovan asleep in a train seat. He opens his eyes. His co is worse. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The train chugs along. A bleary look to his window. Point-of-view: lit by the beginnings of day, the Wall is coming at us, foreshortening, opposite-ways from when we it on Donovan's first trip in. As it sweeps by there is movement and a shout goes up. Donovan stands, gazes out the window in horror. Four figures at the wall. They are riddled with gunfire, dangling and dropping to the eastern side, the other two dropping dead to the western side. Inside the train the passengers react in horror and Donov collapses back into his seat, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: HILTON
dialogues.text: Donovan, haggard, in the restaurant, looking at a menu. A waitress approaches.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I'll start with some coffee, please. And then I’1l have the Hilton Combo, and the American Breakfast. And coffee.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Both breakfasts?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: (handing menu back) Yeah. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: One first, or...

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Both first. Both, whenever they’re ready. And coffee. The waitress moves off. Hoffman approaches, sits.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t be here.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well sometimes in Germany you just want a big American breakfast. Michener and Pinker cross and takes seats at a nearby tab (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: What happened? Where were you last night?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Vogel arranged for me to spend some time in the East.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Not much worse than what you got for me here in the west. So the Russians are fine with the exchange, but Vogel now says the East Germans won't do it. We’re not gonna get Pryor. Hoffman stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Great. Good. So the Soviets are set. We get Powers. We get Powers. Well done. He gives a thumbs up to Michener and Pinker, sitting at a table nearby.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No, the East Germans won't do it. We won’t get Pryor. And look, that kid matters, every person matters.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Sure, that’s why we tried. Abel’s on his way, so we're all set for tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Wait a minute --

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Makes things simple.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: But we’re not getting the kid.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I understand. We’re set. We can ignore the message we got this morning. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leaves. 12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 90. (2)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What message?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: From from the East Germans. They called the number I gave you, said they wanted to speak to you today.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Vogel called?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: No. Office of Harald Ott. East German attorney general.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Wanting what -- what does he want?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: To talk to you, but -- it’s okay, I can’t ask you to go back there. Listen, you seem to be persona non grata to some elements. We won’t push our luck.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: So he wants to see me. What time?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: No no no, now listen, you don’t need to go -- in fact, you shouldn't go. In fact you can’t go. We’re set with the Soviets, we don’t want to screw it up.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: (rising) I’m not going to screw it up.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You're not going, don’t be a pain in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Oh, I ordered. Enjoy your big American breakfast. Several waitresses deposit mountains of food before an abashed Hoffman.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT gl.

dialogues.speaker: CONFERENCE ROOM
dialogues.text: Architecturally grand in a beaux-art manner but cracked a peeling. Furnishings sparse and poor. A heavy middle-aged man shakes Donovan's hand. A male secretary to one side sits taking notes as the Ott and Donovan take their seats at Ott’s desk.. ort I thought it should be negotiated at the highest level. As a courtesy to you.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well I thank you sir. ort I don’t know how things became so confused.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well... I guess sometimes they just do. Female servers clear a large conference table of dishes. ort For sake of clarity, I say we are fully prepared to exchange the so- called student Pryor for Rudolf Abel. I understand from Mr. Vogel that Pryor is very important to you.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yes sir. But -- ort We will do a memorandum to that effect.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: A memorandum. ort (generous) Certainly. We commit to a bilateral exchange --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yes, sure, I’m not sure what you mean, but -- my country also insists on Francis Gary Powers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ort (rising and pounding on the table) No!! One of the women drops her dishware, apologizes.

dialogues.speaker: OTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -- this is how things became confused. Powers -- what use is he, sir? You want him back for punitive reasons? What’s done is done, he has divulged what he will divulge, as no doubt Abel has also. We are offering instead someone who you insist is innocent. And this is right. This is who you should retrieve. The future! Look to the future. A phone among a bank of phones rings. Ott picks up a receiver.

dialogues.speaker: OTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ott! Oops, wrong phone. He picks up another.

dialogues.speaker: OTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ott. He speaks in German for a while, then, to Donovan:

dialogues.speaker: OTT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. If you could give me a moment, sir.

dialogues.speaker: HALLWAY
dialogues.text: Big echoing public space. Donovan is seated on a hard ben Bicycle messengers whiz by in both directions. The secretary’s footsteps echo as he crosses to Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: I am very sorry sir. The Attorney General regrets that he had to leave on urgent business.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: ..-He -- left? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes, many apologies.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I've been waiting for over an hour to --

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Very sorry, sir. He turns and walks away, echoing footsteps, Donovan stari Suddenly Donovan projects:

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Young man! The young man stops, looks back.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-C’mere! Hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -It’s all right, c’mere. The secretary crosses back.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take a seat. He taps the bench next to himself.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh c’mon, c’mon, sit down. Somewhat bewildered, the young man complies. Donovan is friendly:

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: -You like your job here?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (genuine) It’s a very good job, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Must be. Must be interesting.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: And important too. And your English is... good.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes, I hesitate to say excellent, but it is excellent, sir.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Good. Good. Good. See, I just lost my negotiating partner and I need someone to talk to. You seem like a reasonable young man -- can I talk to you? The secretary is lost. His look to Donovan is open, genui and uncomprehending. Donovan helps him:

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--It’s all right, I just...I...1 need you to give a message to your boss. But it has to be very very very clear. You understand?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. But perhaps you should wait until he --

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: No, no, the thing is, I have this cold, I want to get back home, get into bed. (blowing his nose) Can you give the message?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Certainly.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: This is the message. There is no deal for Abel unless we get Powers and Pryor. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: It is arranged for tomorrow morning. It will not happen unless we get two men. Those two men. Two two two. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The secretary is looking into Donovan’s eyes in order to conscientiously remember every word.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: If there is no deal, your boss must tell the Soviets. He has to tell the Soviets that they are not getting Rudolf Abel.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Donovan rises.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: And tell him this: so far Abel has been a good soldier. But he thinks he’s going home. If we have to tell him he’s not going home, the Soviets don't want him, that he’s never going home -- I imagine his behavior might change. And who will be held responsible for that. (He chuckles) That’s a long message! Ya got it all?

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Got it!

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Good. You’re a good man. (steps away; turns back with one last thought) Oh -- and also tell him, no deal unless they let us know by the end of business today. He has the number. If the exchange isn’t gonna happen, no reason for everyone to get up first thing in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: No sir. That would be pointless.

dialogues.speaker: BUSY STREET IN BERLIN
dialogues.text: Donovan is walking with purpose, pulling change from his pocket. Hoffman is just trying to keep up with him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You're kidding me. You’re kidding me. You're kidding me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well. Not really . Need some change!

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: (pulling into his pocket for change) That’s exactly what you weren’t supposed to do.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: My instructions were to feel out the situation.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: (explosive) Your instructions were to get Powers! Not Pryor!! That was not the original deal! You fouled it all up.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: How do you know? I feel pretty good about it. Hoffman hands him the change, almost too angry to speak -

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You fucked it all up!

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Oh don’t worry, I think it’1l be fine. Donovan reaches a phone booth, enters.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: How do you know?! You don’t know that! Hoffman is still staring at him, anger fading as he diges the implications. He looks around at where they are and h public it is. Donovan drops in the coins, in broken Germa places a long distance call to New York.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: (to Hoffman) Look, the whole thing was just to feel me out, will I swap one-for- one. And which one. So I said No, two-for one, so they know where we stand, so it’1ll be fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: What if they think about it, say forget it, you keep our guy, we'll keep your guys?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well then, I have fucked it all up. (suddenly brightens) Hey, honey, it’s me!! Yeah! The fishing’s been great! (throws an evil look to Hoffman as he shuts the door on him) I’m in London. Just for one more meeting, then I’m on my way home. Yeah, yeah I remember that marmalade. It’s that shop right by Regents Park. All right, I will if I have the time. Hey, could I say hi to Roger? Can I say hello to the girls? Is anyone not busy? Have they even noticed I’m not around?

dialogues.speaker: SAFE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Hoffman is sitting quietly, waiting. So is Donovan. They are freezing -- breath visible in the indoor air, and now Hoffman has a cold. A telephone sits in the center of the room on a small table, under a ratty lamp. The the phone rings! Both go for it, as do Michener and Pinker, entering from another room. Hoffman picks it up. Donovan turns and watches Hoffman's face. Hoffman looks a Donovan. Donovan looks at Hoffman. Both unreadable. Slowly, Hoffman hangs up the phone. Unreadable. Finally Hoffman cracks the smallest smile.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: We’re on. Two for one.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Hot dog! Let’s have a drink. He reaches for a bottle on a table.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: One wrinkle.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What’s that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: They won’t release Pryor with Powers. Not at the bridge. They'll release him at the same time -- when the Russians give us Powers on the bridge, they'll release Pryor over at Checkpoint Charlie.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: ...What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I think it means, “We wanna have the last word.”

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: .--But they will do it. A shrug.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: You tell me. You felt ‘em out.

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: The snow-covered Glienicke Bridge. Mid-February: it’s jus before dawn. Morning fog. Gray-blue light. Hoffman and Donovan are at the foot of the bridge, lookin east. The other side: some guard presence, but no officialdom, prisoner. Some pacing from Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Where’s our guy? Where’s their guy - - they’re late.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: (looking through binoculars) Nobody’s late. We’re early.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: May I? He takes the binocs. His look catches on something: Two men in a tower, holding rifles. Snipers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Donovan squints, looks.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hoffman.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I think they have... snipers.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I’m sure they do.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Why are they sure they do?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Because we have snipers. Hoffman swings to the buildings on our side of the bridge revealing our snipers. For the first time Donovan feels t extent to which he is out of his depth, not in control. Engine noise nearby: two cars approaching, from our side. They pull up. Avalon emerges, walks to opposite side passenger door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: AVALON
dialogues.text: Step out, sir. Rudolf Abel steps out, takes in the environment, sees Don on the bridge, waiting for him. His clothes are too big o him as Donovan’s coat is too big on Donovan. Abel, carryi his suitcase, walks to Jim, hand extended.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Dear Jim. How are you. Donovan clasps his hand, shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Happy to see you.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Have you arranged all this for me?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well...let’s see what this is before I take credit for it. Donovan gives a look to Michener on a field telephone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyone word from Pryor at Checkpoint Charlie? Michener speaks into his phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKPOINT CHARLIE
dialogues.text: As at Glienicke Bridge, there is a small military presenc The checkpoint itself is quiet: no traffic. Pinker is summoned to a phone.

dialogues.speaker: PINKER
dialogues.text: Nothin cookin yet.

dialogues.speaker: GLIENICKE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: Michener on the field telephone gives Donovan a headshake Donovan nods acknowledgment. A plainclothes official walks up with a young man in unif

dialogues.speaker: VERONA
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir. This is Lieutenant Joe Murphy. United States Air Force. Here to identify Powers.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Murphy.

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Sir. Abel takes Donovan aside.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: There may be a “glitch.” I was a young man when I left; who will they find to identify me?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I hope it’s not your East German family. I don’t think they could identify each other. A WHISTLE. A sniper gestures to the other side. Engine noise from the other side of the bridge. Two cars arrive. Small figures get out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Our snipers raise rifles. Long lens finding the emerging people, focusing on them. Schischkin is among them. A young man -- Powers -- also among them. Hoffman peering through the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Looks like our party. A beat as the small figures on the opposite side sort themselves out, survey our side. The two parties gazing at each other. Schischkin and another man start walking Powers toward th middle of the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well. Let’s go. You can stay here, Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Not likely. (to guard) Open the gate. He accompanies Abel, Hoffman, and Murphy toward the middl the bridge. Silent beat walking. Then, to Abel:

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...What do you think’11 happen? When you get home?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: I think...I’1l have a vodka. Silent walking.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: But will they -- Rudolf -- is there not the possibility --

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: That my people are going to shoot me?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well...yes. You’re not worried? Abel is ever placid: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Would it help? Murphy is apprehensive as they approach the midpoint, reacting to the quiet. The men stop, just short of midway. A waiting beat. Abel talks to Donovan to his side, but his look remains forward, directed at the men approaching from the other s of the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To answer your question, my friend: I acted honorably. I think they know that. But sometimes people think wrong. People are people. We'll see how they greet me.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What can I look for?

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: If I’m embraced. Or just shown the backseat. Quiet. Crisp footsteps approaching. The other party stops, just short of midway. Total quiet. Floodlights burst on, illuminating both sides. Schischkin steps forward, projects a few words in Russian toward Abel. Abel sets down his suitcase and takes off his hat and glasses, to be more easily identified. He and Schischken exchage words in German. Schischkin motions for Powers to step forward.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Take off the hat. Powers removes his hat. Murphy is looking at the young man many yards away. He ca out:

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Hey, Powers. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Hey, Murph. Utterly superfluously, to Hoffman:

dialogues.speaker: MURPHY
dialogues.text: Yeah, that’s Powers. Schischkin projects:

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: All right, Mr. Donovan. We go now!

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Hang on. He looks back to their side of the bridge: Michener on th field telephone. Feeling their look on him the man looks talks into his phone.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKPOINT CHARLIE
dialogues.text: Pinker with his phone.

dialogues.speaker: PINKER
dialogues.text: Believe me, I’1ll tell you. There's no one here.

dialogues.speaker: GLIENICKE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: Another headshake from his contact. Abel is looking inquisitively at Donovan: what is this?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: They're releasing another man at Checkpoint Charlie. Just waiting for confirmation that he’s there.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: Now -- as per plan, if you please!

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Okay, let’s go. Pryor’ll show up, or he won't; let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: They're waiting to see if we’ll do it without him. We just have to stand here, show them we won't. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: I don’t give a shit what they want, we have our objective. Go ahead Abel. Go ahead sir, you can go.

dialogues.speaker: SCHISCHKIN
dialogues.text: (projecting) If it is not to plan, we go home. We exchange now or we go home. Abel doesn’t understand the back-and-forth. To Donovan:

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: We're waiting for another man?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: You want him too?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I want him.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Doesn't matter what he wants, sir, I’m in charge and you are free to go. Please go. Walk across. Abel is looking at Donovan.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: Stoikey Muzhik. A beat; he decides.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can wait. Hoffman stalks off.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKPOINT CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The contact alerts Pinker in the guard house. Pinker pick up the phone as a car approaches.

dialogues.speaker: PINKER
dialogues.text: It’s something...not sure yet.

dialogues.speaker: GLIENICKE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The contact nods, acknowledging. Calls out to men on the bridge. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTACT
dialogues.text: Hang on!

dialogues.speaker: CHECKPOINT CHARLIE
dialogues.text: The sports car comes to a stop. Vogel and Pryor emerge. Vogel escorting the young man to Pinker.

dialogues.speaker: GLIENICKE BRIDGE
dialogues.text: The contact gives a thumbs up to the men out on the bridg CONTACT (CONT’D) We got him!

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: I sent you a gift, Jim. It’s a painting. I hope it has some meaning to you.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry I didn’t think to get you a gift.

dialogues.speaker: ABEL
dialogues.text: This is your gift. This is your gift. Abel starts across the bridge. As does Powers, from his side. He and Powers pass each other at the center of the bridge They do not look at each other. Powers is arriving. He and Murphy embrace. He and Murphy embrace. Hoffman is urgent.

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: Go. Go. Go. The men move off, all but Donovan who stands facing the o side. He and Abel regard each other from across the gap, Schischken helps - or steers? - Abel into the back seat o his car. Not friendly, not unfriendly. The floodlights go out as Donovan stands there, watching car with Abel pull away.

dialogues.speaker: AIRPORT
dialogues.text: Two sedans pull up outside a cargo plane. The Agents, Donovan and Abel get out.  12.17.14 FINAL SHOOTING SCRIPT 106.

dialogues.speaker: CARGO PLANE INTERIOR
dialogues.text: Powers and Donovan are seated next to each other. Engines are revving. Plainclothes Avalon approaches.

dialogues.speaker: AVALON
dialogues.text: Mr. Donovan. Colonel Abel asked me to give this to you. He hands him a cardboard tube. Powers is looking around, bewildered and apprehensive. To Pinker as he passes:

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Pardon me, sir? Pinker keeps on walking. Hoffman's behind him, and Power snags him.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Were you in charge of this thing, sir?

dialogues.speaker: HOFFMAN
dialogues.text: (curt) Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS
dialogues.text: Well I gotta thank you, I gotta thank somebody -- Hoffman does not acknowledge. He brushes past him to take seat further back. Powers, hung out to dry, watches him go. With a hurt look he turns to Donovan, only because Donova next to him.

dialogues.speaker: POWERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I gave them nothing. I gave them nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: It doesn’t matter. It doesn’t matter what people think. You know what you did. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Donovan opens the cardboard tube, withdraws a rolled-up painting. An excellent portrait of himself.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN HOME
dialogues.text: Donovan stands outside his house, gazing at it, suitcase his side. He removes his hat, lifts his suitcase and approaches the front steps as a beaming Mary emerges onto veranda.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well. Welcome home! Donovan climbs the steps and sets down his suitcase and h

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What a trip. They kiss and embrace, him holding her a little closer an longer than ordinary.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: «..You okay?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I’m fine.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You get the marmalade?

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Yes, yup, yup. He retrieves a jar and hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Good. (she inspects it) Jim!

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: This is from Arno’s! On the corner!

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: Well, honey, I was busy --

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Oh for Pete’s sake...

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, we were so busy. Where’s Roger, is he home? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: He’s home. Carol’s home. Peggy’s home. Everyone’s home. Roger's voice is heard shouting from another room.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom, come quick! Look! She runs into the house.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN HOME
dialogues.text: Mary arrives at the threshold to watch Roger, Carol, Pegg and Doug crowded in front of the TV. Mary holds her breat as the President’s press secretary, PIERRE SALINGER, addresses the nation’s media.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Francis Gary Powers has been released from prison in the Soviet Union, and turned over to American authorities early this morning in Berlin. The president has commuted the sentence of Rudolf Abel. Mr. Abel has been deported, and has been released in Berlin. In B.G. Donovan enters the house and continues on past th living room.

dialogues.speaker: SALINGER, (ON TV)
dialogues.text: Efforts to obtain Mr. Powers’ release had been underway for some time -- in recent efforts, the United States Government has had the cooperation and assistance of Mr. James B. Donovan, a New York attorney. Mary can’t believe what she’s hearing.

dialogues.speaker: PEGGY
dialogues.text: I thought Daddy was fishing. For salmon. Mary turns, expecting to see Donovan behind her, but he’s there. She moves toward the staircase, sees his suitcase the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DONOVAN HOME
dialogues.text: Mary comes up the stairs and enters the room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Donovan is face down on the made bed, fully dressed, and finally sound asleep. Mary picks his hat up off the floor and just stands there looking at him, her eyes filling with tears.

dialogues.speaker: TRAIN
dialogues.text: Subway, the next day. Donovan riding into work. He sits b the window as he did on the S-Bahn but now, finally, look like he’s had a good night’s sleep. Passengers on the train are reading their newspapers, headlines about the spy exchange. One woman - the same wo who once looked at him disapprovingly - looks below the f and sees a photo of Donovan. Recognizes him sitting acros from her. She smiles. He is uncomfortable, but then he smiles too. His look drifts to his window. His point-of-view: Brooklyn sweeping by. More benign than was Berlin. His peaceful expression darkens as the train passes backyards where a group of kinds are climbing a fe dropping to the other side... The camera holds on the tra interior, Donovan continuing to gaze out the window...

dialogues.speaker: TITLES
dialogues.text: Following his return to Russia, Rudolf Abel was reunited his wife and daughter. He was never publicly acknowledged the Soviet Union as a spy. Gary Powers died in a helicopter crash in 1977, while wor for KNBC News. He was posthumously awarded the CIA Director's Medal and the USAF POW Medal in 2000 and the Silver Star in 2012. In 1962, Frederic L. Pryor received his Ph.D. in Economic from Yale University. He is currently professor Emeritus Economics and Senior Research Scholar at Swarthmore Colle Following the successful conclusion of the Powers-Abel exchange, Donovan was asked by President Kennedy to under further negotiations on behalf of the US. In the summer o 1962 he was sent to Cuba to discuss with Fidel Castro ter to obtain the release of 1,113 prisoners held after the B of Pigs invasion. When Donovan finished negotiations, he had secured the release of 9,703 men, women and children.
